policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing system configuration practices including least functionality principles
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.06 requires 'configure the system to provide only mission-essential capabilities' which necessitates formal policy guidance on reducing system functionality to essential services only

policies.name: Port and Protocol Management Policy
policies.description: Policy defining approved functions, ports, protocols, connections, and services for organizational systems
policies.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.06.b explicitly requires organizations to 'prohibit or restrict use of functions, ports, protocols, connections, and services' requiring formal policy definition of what is allowed

procedures.name: System Functionality Review Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for periodic review of system functions, ports, protocols, connections, and services to identify unnecessary or nonsecure items
procedures.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.06.c mandates periodic review to identify unnecessary or nonsecure functions, ports, protocols, connections, and services

procedures.name: Service Hardening Procedure
procedures.description: Procedure for disabling or removing unnecessary functions, ports, protocols, connections, and services from systems
procedures.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.06.d requires organizations to disable or remove unnecessary or nonsecure system components, necessitating documented procedures for safely performing these actions

procedures.name: Least Functionality Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Procedure for configuring systems to provide only mission-essential capabilities, including baseline configurations for different system types
procedures.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.06.a mandates configuring systems to provide only mission-essential capabilities, requiring documented process for determining and implementing minimal necessary functionality

executionEvidence.name: Quarterly System Functionality Reviews
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: systems reviewed, functions/ports/protocols assessed, unnecessary items identified, nonsecure components flagged, remediation actions taken, reviewer signatures, review completion date
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST requires periodic review per 03.04.06.c; quarterly aligns with CIS Critical Security Control 4.1 recommendation for enterprise asset management reviews

executionEvidence.name: Network Port Scan Results
executionEvidence.description: Automated port scan reports showing: systems scanned, open ports discovered, port-to-service mapping, unauthorized services flagged, scan date, scanning tool used
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states 'organizations can employ network scanning tools...to identify and prevent the use of prohibited functions, ports, protocols, system connections, and services'; monthly scanning provides continuous monitoring

executionEvidence.name: System Configuration Baselines
executionEvidence.description: Documented baseline configurations showing: approved services enabled, disabled services/protocols, firewall rules, network service restrictions, configuration validation date, approval signatures
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.06.a requires systems be configured to provide only mission-essential capabilities; baselines document approved minimal configurations

executionEvidence.name: Service Disablement Change Tickets
executionEvidence.description: Change management tickets showing: service/port/protocol disabled, justification for removal, system affected, date implemented, implementer, approver, testing results
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.06.d mandates disabling or removing unnecessary components; change tickets provide audit trail of remediation actions

executionEvidence.name: Endpoint Protection System Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports from host-based firewalls and intrusion detection systems showing: blocked connection attempts, prohibited protocol usage attempts, date/time of blocks, affected systems, remediation actions
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states 'endpoint protection systems (e.g., firewalls and host-based intrusion detection systems) identify and prevent the use of prohibited functions, ports, protocols, system connections, and services'

operationalActivities: Configure systems to provide only mission-essential capabilities and functions
Define and document prohibited functions, ports, protocols, connections, and services
Review systems quarterly to identify unnecessary or nonsecure components
Disable or remove FTP, Bluetooth, peer-to-peer networking and other unnecessary protocols
Disable unused physical and logical network ports
Conduct monthly port scans to identify unauthorized services
Maintain configuration baselines showing minimal approved functionality
Use endpoint protection systems to prevent use of prohibited services
Document and track all service disablement changes through change management

policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing software management and change control practices
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.08 requires implementing deny-all, allow-by-exception policy for software execution which necessitates formal policy guidance on software control approach

policies.name: Software Authorization Policy
policies.description: Policy defining criteria for software approval, prohibited software categories, and user installation restrictions
policies.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.08 mandates identifying authorized software programs and implementing allow-by-exception approach, requiring formal policy on what software is permitted and approval process

procedures.name: Software Whitelist Management Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for adding, reviewing, and removing software from authorized software list including version control and source verification
procedures.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.08.a requires identifying software programs authorized to execute; procedure needed for maintaining accurate whitelist

procedures.name: Application Control Implementation Procedure
procedures.description: Procedure for configuring and maintaining application control technologies (AppLocker, WDAC, or equivalent) to enforce deny-all, allow-by-exception policy
procedures.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.08.b mandates implementing deny-all, allow-by-exception policy requiring documented process for technical enforcement mechanisms

procedures.name: Software Request and Approval Procedure
procedures.description: Process for users to request new software, evaluation criteria, approval workflow, and installation authorization
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states 'organizations identify permitted and prohibited actions regarding software installation' including 'organization-approved app stores'; requires formal request/approval process

executionEvidence.name: Authorized Software Whitelist
executionEvidence.description: Current list showing: software name, vendor, approved versions, allowed execution paths, approval date, approver, business justification, license information, specific sources authorized
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.08.a explicitly requires identifying software programs authorized to execute; whitelist is the core implementation artifact

executionEvidence.name: Quarterly Software Whitelist Reviews
executionEvidence.description: Review reports showing: software reviewed, obsolete software removed, new software approved, version updates assessed, unauthorized software discovered, reviewer signatures, review completion date
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.08.c mandates reviewing and updating authorized software list at organization-defined frequency; quarterly aligns with standard change management cycles

executionEvidence.name: Application Control Policy Configuration
executionEvidence.description: Technical configuration documentation showing: application control technology deployed (AppLocker/WDAC/equivalent), deny-all policy configured, whitelist rules implemented, enforcement mode enabled, policy deployment status, last update date
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.08.b requires implementing deny-all, allow-by-exception policy; configuration documentation proves technical enforcement is active

executionEvidence.name: Blocked Software Execution Logs
executionEvidence.description: Security logs showing: blocked executable name, attempting user, system affected, date/time of block, file hash, execution path attempted, block reason
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion emphasizes 'policy enforcement methods can include automated methods'; blocked execution logs demonstrate active enforcement and identify potential policy violations

executionEvidence.name: Software Installation Approval Tickets
executionEvidence.description: Helpdesk/change tickets showing: software requested, requesting user, business justification, security review results, approver, installation date, whitelist update confirmation
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states organizations identify 'permitted software installations include updates and security patches...and downloading from organization-approved app stores'; tickets document approval workflow

executionEvidence.name: Application Inventory vs Whitelist Comparison
executionEvidence.description: Reports comparing discovered installed software against authorized whitelist showing: compliant installations, unauthorized software detected, remediation actions, variance percentage, discovery date
executionEvidence.rationale: Periodic comparison validates that only authorized software is actually installed and identifies drift from approved baseline for investigation and remediation

operationalActivities: Maintain current whitelist of all authorized software programs including versions and sources
Implement application control technology enforcing deny-all, allow-by-exception policy
Review and update authorized software list quarterly
Process software installation requests through formal approval workflow
Configure AppLocker, WDAC, or equivalent to block unauthorized software execution
Monitor and investigate blocked software execution attempts daily
Remove obsolete or unused software from whitelist during quarterly reviews
Validate application control policies are deployed and enforced on all systems
Compare installed software inventory against whitelist monthly to identify unauthorized applications
Document business justification for all approved software additions

policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing system component tracking and inventory management practices
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.10 requires developing and documenting system component inventory which necessitates formal policy guidance on asset tracking and accountability

policies.name: Asset Management Policy
policies.description: Policy defining asset lifecycle management, inventory accuracy requirements, component accountability standards, and required tracking attributes
policies.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.10 mandates comprehensive inventory with specific accountability information; formal policy needed to define organizational requirements for asset management

procedures.name: Asset Inventory Creation and Maintenance Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for adding new components to inventory, updating existing records, and removing decommissioned components including required data fields and verification steps
procedures.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.10.a requires developing and documenting inventory that accurately reflects the system; procedure needed for consistent inventory management

procedures.name: System Component Discovery Procedure
procedures.description: Procedure for automated and manual discovery of hardware, software, and firmware components including network scanning, agent-based inventory tools, and physical verification
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states inventory must include all components within the system; requires systematic discovery process to ensure completeness and accuracy

procedures.name: Inventory Reconciliation Procedure
procedures.description: Process for comparing automated discovery results against documented inventory, investigating discrepancies, and updating records to match actual deployed components
procedures.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.10.a specifies inventory must accurately reflect the system; reconciliation procedure ensures inventory remains synchronized with reality

executionEvidence.name: Current System Component Inventory Database
executionEvidence.description: Complete inventory listing showing: hardware (servers, workstations, network devices, mobile devices) with component type, physical location, manufacturer, model, serial number, network addresses (IPv4/IPv6), date of receipt, cost; software with name, vendor, version, license info, owner; firmware with version, device installed on, update date
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.10.a explicitly requires developing and documenting inventory; NIST discussion specifies required information includes component type, physical location, manufacturer, model, serial number, supplier, cost, network addresses, software versions, and license info

executionEvidence.name: Quarterly Inventory Review and Audit Reports
executionEvidence.description: Review reports showing: total components inventoried, new components added, components removed/decommissioned, inventory accuracy percentage, discrepancies identified, corrective actions taken, reviewer signatures, review completion date
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.10.b mandates reviewing and updating inventory at organization-defined frequency; quarterly reviews align with standard asset management practices and provide reasonable verification cycle

executionEvidence.name: Component Addition/Removal Change Logs
executionEvidence.description: Change logs showing: component added or removed, date of change, change ticket reference, person responsible, verification that inventory was updated, before/after inventory counts
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requirement 03.04.10.c explicitly requires updating inventory as part of installations, removals, and system updates; change logs prove inventory is maintained in real-time

executionEvidence.name: Network Discovery Scan Results
executionEvidence.description: Automated discovery scan reports showing: systems discovered on network, IP addresses, MAC addresses, operating systems, open ports, installed software detected, scan date, comparison to inventory database, unrecognized devices flagged
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion emphasizes inventory must include 'machine names and network addresses for all implemented protocols' for networked components; automated discovery validates inventory accuracy and identifies shadow IT

executionEvidence.name: Physical Asset Verification Records
executionEvidence.description: Physical verification records showing: asset tag number, component location, physical condition, custodian verified, verification date, verifier signature, discrepancies noted
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion requires 'physical location' in inventory specifications; periodic physical verification ensures inventory accuracy for location and existence of hardware assets

executionEvidence.name: Software License Compliance Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: software product, licenses purchased, installations detected, compliance status, license expiration dates, license server data, audit date
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion explicitly requires 'software license information' in inventory; compliance reports validate license tracking and prevent unlicensed software usage

operationalActivities: Maintain centralized inventory database of all hardware, software, and firmware components
Assign and affix asset tags to physical hardware components
Update inventory within 24 hours of component installations, removals, or updates
Conduct quarterly reviews of complete system component inventory
Perform weekly automated network discovery scans to identify new or changed components
Document required accountability information: system name, owners, versions, licenses, specifications, locations, network addresses, serial numbers, cost, supplier
Reconcile automated discovery results with documented inventory monthly
Perform annual physical verification of hardware assets and locations
Track software license information and monitor compliance quarterly
Investigate and resolve inventory discrepancies within 30 days of identification
Ensure inventory includes granularity necessary for tracking and reporting (component-level detail)
Prevent duplicate component accounting across multiple systems
